[[File:US Navy 030620-N-8937A-002 Lt. William Peterson (left) of Branch Dental Clinic Sasebo, Japan drills a cavity while his dental assistant, Miho Otubo, ensures the area remains clean.jpg|thumb|Dental assistant on the right supporting a dental operator on the left, during a procedure.]] '''Dental assistants''' (also known as dental nurses) are members of the dental team.<ref name="Kracher_2017" /> They may support a dental operator (such as a [[dentist]] or other treating [[dental auxiliary]]) in providing more efficient [[dentistry|dental treatment]]. ''Dental assistants'' are distinguished from other groups of [[Dental auxiliary|dental auxiliaries]] (such as [[dental therapist]]s, [[dental hygienist]]s and [[dental technician]]s) by differing training, roles and patient scopes.<ref name="ADA_Careers" /><ref name="Kracher_2017" />
== History ==
=== The first dental assistant === [[File:Dr. James McCarl and dental assistant with young patient.jpg|thumb|Infection control was very different in historical dentistry when compared to dentistry nowadays in 2018. Dental assistants and dentists did not wear all or if any personal protection equipment when practicing. We can see that the dentist, in this case on the left, is not wearing a mask, gloves or eye protection (apart from his glasses). Additionally, the dental assistant on the right, is also not wearing any gloves, mask or eye protection.]] The first dental assistant in modern history is believed to trace back to 1885. Dr Edmund Kells, a pioneering dentist operating from New Orleans, enlisted the help of his wife, Malvina Cueria to assist him during dental procedures.<ref name="Langland_1972">{{cite journal | vauthors = Langland OE | title = C. Edmund Kells | journal = Oral Surgery, Oral Medicine, and Oral Pathology | volume = 34 | issue = 4 | pages = 680–9 | date = October 1972 | pmid = 4560600 | doi = 10.1016/0030-4220(72)90353-2 }}</ref><ref name="DCE">{{cite web|url=https://www.dentalcareersedu.org/2015/06/the-birth-of-the-dental-assistant-profession/|title=The Birth of the Dental Assistant Profession |date=2015 | website = Dental Careers Education }}</ref> The dental field was initially dominated by males, but after this first addition of a female, it was then acceptable for women to seek dental treatment without their husbands. This led to dental assistants of that era also being known as "Ladies in Attendance".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hunter|first=Tija | name-list-format = vanc |date=2011|title=Assisting; Past present, and future|url=https://www.dentistryiq.com/articles/2011/12/assisting--past-present.html|journal=Dentistry IQ }}</ref> Thanks to the addition of [[Women in dentistry|women to dentistry]], the profession flourished with more and more women seeking treatment and more patients overall receiving care.<ref name="DCE" />
=== The first association === It was not until almost four decades later that in 1923 the first dental assistant association was founded by [[Juliette southard|Juliette Southard]], named the American Dental Assistant Association and it is still in practise now.<ref name="ADAA">{{cite web|url=https://www.adaausa.org/About-ADAA/History-of-ADAA|title=History of ADAA|last=|first=|date=2018| website = American Dental Assistants Association }}</ref> It began with just five members, now reaching more than 10,000.<ref name="ADAA" />
== Roles ==
The dental assistant's role is often thought to be to support the dental operator by typically passing [[Dental instruments|instruments]] during clinical procedures. However, in fact, their role extends much further to include: providing patients help with their oral hygiene skills, preparing the patient for treatment, sterilising instruments, assisting during general anaesthetic dental procedures, positioning suction devices, exposing dental [[Radiography|radiographs]], taking [[dental impression]]s, recording patient notes and administration roles such as scheduling appointments.<ref name="ADA_Careers">{{cite web | url = https://www.adansw.com.au/Careers/Dental-Assistant | website = Australian Dental Association |date=16 May 2018| title = Dental Assistant }}</ref>
[[File:ATOMO_Dental_premium_quality_barrier_film_for_dental_clinics.jpg|thumb|Plastic barriers that are typically used to cover dental equipment for infection control purposes.]]
=== Infection control === It was customary for oral health care workers and dental assistants in the 1980s to practice oral health care without wearing gloves, masks or eye protection.<ref name="Oosthuysen_2014">{{cite journal | vauthors = Oosthuysen J, Potgieter E, Fossey A | title = Compliance with infection prevention and control in oral health-care facilities: a global perspective | journal = International Dental Journal | volume = 64 | issue = 6 | pages = 297–311 | date = December 2014 | pmid = 25244364 | doi = 10.1111/idj.12134 }}</ref> This was at a crucial time due to the [[Human Immunodeficiency Virus|human immunodeficiency virus]] (HIV) spreading rapidly at a global rate.<ref name="Oosthuysen_2014" /> However, in 2018 gloves, masks and eye protection have become part of the standard [[infection control]] guidelines which has been implemented in all oral health care settings as a means of preventing the spread of [[Infectious Disease|infectious disease]].<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control">{{cite web|url=https://www.ada.org.au/Dental-Professionals/Publications/Infection-Control/Guidelines-for-Infection-Control/1ADA_GuidelinesforInfectionControl_3|title=Guidelines for Infection Control| website = Australia Dental Association }}</ref> [[Infection control]] in oral health care not only protects the patient but it also protects the oral health care workers.<ref name="Oosthuysen_2014" /> This includes: [[dentist]]s, dental specialists, oral health therapists, dental hygienists and dental assistants.<ref name="Oosthuysen_2014" />
Dental assistants play a crucial role in maintaining high levels of [[infection control]] in the oral health care setting.<ref name="Oosthuysen_2014" /> The dental assistant is the major link between oral health care workers and the patient.<ref name="Manasi_2016">{{cite journal | vauthors = Manasi R|date= December 2016 | title=Awareness about Occupational Exposure for Blood Borne Infections among Medical and Dental Students |journal=Journal of Medical Science and Clinical Research|volume=04|issue=12|pages=14898–14902|doi=10.18535/jmscr/v4i12.96 }}</ref> To perform infection control responsibilities well, the dental assistant must have the appropriate education, training and work experience. Examples of infection control protocols that the dental assistant needs to follow in an oral health setting include:
=== Hand hygiene ===
[[Hand washing|Hand hygiene]] aims to reduce the number of [[microorganism]]s on hands. [[Antimicrobial agents]] such as alcohol-based hand rub or [[antimicrobial]] soap and water are effective agents to remove most [[antimicrobial agents|antimicrobial]] [[bacteria]] on hands in dental settings.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /><ref name="Manasi_2016" />
=== Personal protective equipment (PPE) ===
Gloves, gown and eye protection are essential barrier protection items that enable the dental assistant to reduce the transmission of [[infectious diseases]] to themselves, other dental co-workers and patients.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /><ref name="Manasi_2016" /> Gloves and masks need to be disposed after each patient, eyewear can be disposable or reusable and gowns need to be replaced if visibly soiled.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /><ref name="Manasi_2016" /> Lastly, footwear must include leather closed toe shoes; this minimises the risk of sharps injury.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" />
=== Surgical procedures and aseptic technique ===
It is crucial to wear sterile gloves when the dental assistant is assisting in surgery with the oral health care clinician.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> Hand hygiene using [[antimicrobial]] soap and water is imperial to maintaining adequate [[infection control]] in this setting, as this minimises the risk of [[infection]].<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" />
=== Management of sharps injury ===
It is crucial that sharp instruments which include: needles, scalers, scalpels, burs, orthodontics bands and endodontic files need to be handled with care and appropriate techniques to minimise any potential sharps injury.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> Sharps also need to be disposed accordingly into the sharps containers, separate from other disposable bins.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> The dental assistant needs to be aware of what is required to go into the sharps containers and what is not.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> This minimises the chance of spreading [[infectious diseases]].<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> [[File:Container_for_medical_sharp_and_infectious_waste.jpg|thumb|Container for medical sharps and infectious waste - typically found in dental surgeries.]]
=== Management of clinical waste ===
It is imperative that when performing change over, that the dental assistant is able to distinguish the difference between medical related waste compared to contaminated waste.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> Contaminated waste needs to be placed in a leak proof thick yellow bag with a [[biohazard symbol]] label.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" />
=== Environment ===
The dental assistant should put on new gloves when cleaning working surfaces during the changeover between patients.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> They must also be able to distinguish between clean and dirty zones as this minimises the spread of [[infectious diseases]] between co-workers and patients.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> Additionally, plastic barriers are placed on: instruments such as; hand pieces connected to the chair, overhead lights, amalgamators, [[x-ray machine]]s, mixing materials and other miscellaneous [[dental instruments]], materials or appliances.<ref name="Prathima_2017">{{Cite journal| vauthors = Prathima V, Vellore KP, Kotha A, Malathi S, Kumar VS, Koneru M | date = May 2017 | title = Knowledge, attitude and practices towards eco-friendly dentistry among dental practitioners | url = http://portaldeperiodicos.unisul.br/index.php/JR_Dentistry/article/view/4816 | journal = Journal of Research in Dentistry | volume = 4 | issue = 4 | pages = 123–127 }}</ref> One of the roles that the dental assistant participates in is changing these plastic barriers after each patient has left that surgery.<ref name="Prathima_2017" /> This ensures that the surgery is set up ready for the next patient.<ref name="Prathima_2017" />
* These infection control procedures and protocols not only apply to the dental assistant, but to all co-workers in the oral health care setting.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> However, the dental assistant is the major connection between the patient and the oral health care clinician.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" /> Therefore, it is imperative that they follow these guidelines to minimise the risk of spreading possible [[infectious diseases]] to co-workers, patients and themselves.<ref name="ADA_Infection_Control" />
=== Sterilisation, disinfectant and antiseptic === Dental assistants play a large role in ensuring that the reusable [[dental instruments]] used daily in dental practices are sterilised adequately after each use.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Ball | first1 = Samantha | name-list-format = vanc | title = Duty of care | journal = Dental Nursing | date = September 2011 | volume = 7 | issue = Sup1 | pages = S4–S5 | doi = 10.12968/denn.2011.7.Sup1.4 }}</ref> [[Sterilization (microbiology)|Sterilisation]] is an essential part of the [[infection control]] protocol. This can be defined as free of all life forms where the elimination of considerable number of the most heat resistant spores (bacterial and mycotic) is the basic criteria sterilisation. Sterilisation process consists of<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bev|first=Wasp | name-list-format = vanc |date=October 2013|title=A Review of Pre-Sterilisation Cleaning Methods | doi = 10.12968/denn.2013.9.Sup2.20 |journal=Dental Nursing|volume=9|pages=20–24 }}</ref>
# [[Autoclaving]] where moist heat kills bacteria by denaturation of high protein- containing bacteria at 250F (121 °C) for 15 to 20 minutes or 270 F for 3 minutes. Biological monitors and Process indicators are 2 methods used to ensure the effectiveness of sterilization process. ## Biological monitor (spore test) where bacterial spores are placed in strips or envelops along with the instruments. This method shows that the microorganisms have been eradicated and must be conducted weekly. ## Process indicators; where the load has reached a certain temperature, the indicators change their colour. # [[Dry heat sterilization]] which requires a higher temperature and longer time (1–2 hours) than steam autoclave, therefore, only glass or metal objects can be steamed by dry heat. # Chemiclave by using Ethylene oxide at relatively low temperature for 2–3 hours. # Cold/ chemical test which can be done by soaking instruments (heat- sensitive) in a specific chemical solution such as 2% glutaraldehyde for 10 hours in order to kill bacterial spores. However, this method does not destroy hepatitis viruses and spores.
[[Disinfectant]] is also one of the major roles of dental assistant where chemicals applied to inanimate surfaces such as lab tops, counter tops, headrests, light handles, etc. This is to make sure that germicide and/or microbiostatic are achieved.<ref name = "US">{{cite web | url = http://sydney.edu.au/whs/guidelines/biosafety/decontamination_guidelines.shtml |title=Decontamination of Decontamination of Clinical/Biological Waste and Spill Management | publisher = The University of Sydney }}</ref> [[Antiseptic Principle of the Practice of Surgery|Antiseptic]] chemical agents similar to disinfectants but they may be applied safely to living tissue, is another task for dental assistant where Alcohol is the most commonly used.<ref name = "US" />
=== Health promotion === Dental assistants make a difference in the community by participating in [[health promotion]] activities and programs. These programs may take place at schools, preschools, [[immunisation]] events or at [[maternal health]] clinics. Dental operators may also be supported by dental assistants during pre-school or school screenings.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hall M, Christian B | title = A health-promoting community dental service in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia: protocol for the North Richmond model of oral health care | journal = Australian Journal of Primary Health | volume = 23 | issue = 5 | pages = 407–414 | date = October 2017 | pmid = 28823310 | doi = 10.1071/PY17007 }}</ref>
Dental assistants can extend their scope to provide oral health promotion to patients in Australia by completing the Certificate IV in Dental Assisting (Oral Health Promotion).<ref name="Dyer_2014">{{cite journal | vauthors = Dyer TA, Brocklehurst P, Glenny AM, Davies L, Tickle M, Issac A, Robinson PG | title = Dental auxiliaries for dental care traditionally provided by dentists | journal = The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews | volume = | issue = 8 | pages = CD010076 | date = August 2014 | pmid = 25140869 | doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD010076.pub2 }}</ref> The dental assistant will have the ability to implement an individualised oral health promotion program and oral hygiene program. After the appropriate training the dental assistant may; [[File:Group session oral health promotion Nepal.JPG|thumb|Health promotion for good oral health.]] [[File:Altenheim 05.jpg|thumb|Residential aged care and dental assistants engaging in recreational activities - its not always about teeth.]]
# Promote the dental team concept in achieving good oral health and promoting good oral hygiene habits # Assist in making dental treatment accessible and affordable to the community # Perform health promotion activities by promoting good oral health to the community # Support and educate on oral health promotion to allied health professionals
Dental assistants help other dental and allied health professionals in health promotion. These dental assistants implement oral health programs by providing resources and presentation promoting oral health messages to several target groups and community settings.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Petersen PE, Torres AM | title = Preventive oral health care and health promotion provided for children and adolescents by the Municipal Dental Health Service in Denmark | journal = International Journal of Paediatric Dentistry | volume = 9 | issue = 2 | pages = 81–91 | date = June 1999 | pmid = 10530216 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-263x.1999.00111.x }}</ref> These settings include:
* [[Assisted living|Residential Aged Care]] Facilities * [[Special needs dentistry|Special Needs]] * Schools * Early childhood services * Culturally diverse communities * Community sport clubs
Dental assistant can educate the community and schools by advising on:
* Oral diseases * Diet analysis and counselling * Oral hygiene strategies * Preventive strategies * Care of fixed & removable prosthesis and fixed appliances * [[Smoking cessation]] * Preventing sports injuries
=== Radiography === Currently in [[Australia]], dental assistants are not required to be registered under the Dental Board of Australia.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /> However, dental assistants who have attained their certificate IV in dental assisting – [[Dental radiography|Dental Radiography]] must hold a current license with the relative state or territory radiation authority.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /> Dental assistants that decide to take on further study into their certificate IV in dental assisting - dental radiography, have an advantage of exposing patients to radiation also known as an x-ray, with regards to oral health care.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /> The dental assistant will take training to further their practical and theoretical skills relevant to the role of the dental radiographer.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /> [[File:Dental Radiography.JPG|thumb|Dental Radiography - pictures of intra oral radiographs of the whole mouth.]]Upon successful completion of the training program dependent on the course structure, the dental assistant may:
Expose [[Intraoral|intra-oral]] radiographs that ensures an optimum radiographic image.<ref name="DNA_Short_Course">{{cite web | url = http://www.dentalnursingaustralia.com/SHORT%20COURSE%20DENTAL%20RADIOGRAPHY%202015.pdf|title = Short Course Dental Radiology| website = Dental Nursing Australia}}</ref>
*<nowiki/>Process, mount and file [[Intraoral|intra-ora]]<nowiki/>l radiographs.<ref name="DNA_Short_Course" /> * Able to identify technical faults<nowiki/> and their causes.<ref name="DNA_Short_Course" /> * Be able to demonstrate an understanding of potential hazards of exposure to [[radiation]] and to practice high standards of [[radiation therapy]].<ref name="DNA_Short_Course" /> * To recognise normal [[anatomy]].<ref name="DNA_Short_Course" /> * Maintain [[infection control]] throughout all practical procedures.<ref name="DNA_Short_Course" />
== Potential future roles ==
=== Aging population === [[File:Basic_dental_screening_150218-N-QK202-017.jpg|thumb|School screening where children are screened for dental decay or gum disease or other abnormalities of the mouth.]]Looking to the future of dentistry and oral health, the roles for dental assistants are ever-changing and expanding. With the increase in an ageing population, it will become more and more commonplace for dental assistants to be employed to support dental operators with providing oral health promotion and treatment within [[Residential care facility|residential care]] facilities.<ref>{{cite book | title = Better oral health in residential care: staff portfolio | date = 2009 | publisher = South Australian Dental Service, Government of South Australia | location = Adelaide | isbn = 978-0-7308-9791-0 }}</ref>
=== Increasing demand to match new dental graduates ===
The number of newly graduated dentists and dental auxiliaries is increasing and with that the need for dental assistants.<ref name="Kracher_2017">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kracher C, Breen C, McMahon K, Gagliardi L, Miyasaki C, Landsberg K, Reed C | title = The Evolution of the Dental Assisting Profession | journal = Journal of Dental Education | volume = 81 | issue = 9 | pages = eS30–eS37 | date = September 2017 | pmid = 28864801 | doi = 10.21815/JDE.017.031 }}</ref> According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of America the rate of employed dental assistants will likely increase by 18% in the ten years between 2014 and 2024.<ref name="Kracher_2017" /> With an increase in dental assistants comes the possibility of extension in the dental assistant roles and scope. As seen in some states of the United States of America, dental assistants are able to perform some simple [[Dental filling|fillings]] with the supervision of a practising dentist.<ref name="Kracher_2017" /> By allowing dental assistants to extend their scope alongside the appropriate training, the workload of the other members of the dental team is lessened and increases efficiency of the dental clinic management. This may have the potential to reach other countries in the future as the need for dental and oral health treatments increase.<ref name="Kracher_2017" />
== Variations around the world == Dental assistant roles can vary depending on different country qualifications and regulations. Below are examples of dental assisting roles which the dental assistant is able to perform, respective to that country.
=== Australia === [[File:Australian_Flag_Flying_animated.gif|thumb|Australian Flag - animated.]] According to the Australian Government, Department of Health, in 2006 there were 15,381 registered dental assistants supporting dental operators. Of those, 171 were Indigenous.
In Australia Dental Assistants should have the following skills:<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.ada.org.au/Careers/Dental-Team/Assistant | title = Careers in Dentistry - Australian Dental Association| website = Australian Dental Association |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Paschall L | title = The professional dental assistant | journal = Dental Assistant | volume = 83 | issue = 1 | pages = 4, 47 | date = January 2014 | pmid = 24741898 }}</ref>
* have excellent communication skills<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Breen C | title = Tips to enhance effective communication skills for the dental assistant | journal = Dental Assistant | volume = 82 | issue = 1 | pages = 4, 6 | date = January 2013 | pmid = 23513388 }}</ref> * enjoy interacting with other people * be organised and an efficient manager of their time * be meticulous and pays great attention to detail * possess good manual dexterity * enjoy responsibility * have the ability to comprehend and follow instructions * be skilled at multitasking
Dental Assistants work as part of a wider dental team, primarily with Dentists, but also with Dental Specialists, Oral Health Therapists, Dental Therapists, Dental Technitions, Dental Hygienists and Dental Prosthetists.<ref>{{Cite book| date = May 2012 | editor-last = Limeback | editor-first = Hardy | name-list-format = vanc | title = Comprehensive Preventive Dentistry | doi = 10.1002/9781118703762 | publisher = Wiley-Blackwell | location = Ames, Iowa | isbn = 978-1-118-70376-2 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Segal L, Marsh C, Heyes R | title = The real cost of training health professionals in Australia: it costs as much to build a dietician workforce as a dental workforce | journal = Journal of Health Services Research & Policy | volume = 22 | issue = 2 | pages = 91–98 | date = April 2017 | pmid = 28429975 | doi = 10.1177/1355819616668202 | pmc = 5347354 }}</ref>
Tasks include:<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/0/6BC5CD4E5870A816CA2571E20083552B?opendocument | title = Australian and New Zealand Standard Classification of Occupations: UNIT GROUP 4232 Dental Assistants | publisher = Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) | year = 2006 |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = McMullen G | title = The ideal dental assistant. What makes an exceptional dental assistant? | journal = Ontario Dentist | volume = 74 | issue = 2 | pages = 31–2, 34 | date = March 1997 | pmid = 9470599 }}</ref>
* receiving and preparing patients<ref name="Hall_2017">{{cite journal | vauthors = Hall M, Christian B | title = A health-promoting community dental service in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia: protocol for the North Richmond model of oral health care | journal = Australian Journal of Primary Health | volume = 23 | issue = 5 | pages = 407–414 | date = October 2017 | pmid = 28823310 | doi = 10.1071/py17007 }}</ref> *[[File:Dentist.2.jpg|thumb|Dental practitioner and dental assistant working in conjunction with one another.]]arranging and handing instruments, medication, and other dental requisites to Dental Practitioners * preparing dental materials and processing X-rays * using suction devices and water sprays * performing routine maintenance on equipment * sterilising and preventing cross infection of equipment<ref name="Manasi_2016" /> * may advise patients on dental health education and post-operative care and procedures<ref name="Hall_2017" /> * may act as receptionist for Dental Practitioners *may perform billing and other clerical tasks

Australian Dental assistants perform limited and restricted duties and are not permitted to perform any of the following:<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia">{{cite web|url=http://www.dapa.asn.au/home/working-in-australia|title= Working in Australia | website = The Dental Assistants Professional Association |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref><ref name="Fraser_1995">{{cite journal | vauthors = Fraser HJ | title = The training and examination of dental nurses in New Zealand and Australia | journal = British Dental Nurses' Journal | volume = 54 | issue = 3 | pages = 12 | date = 1995 | pmid = 9790009 }}</ref>
* any irreversible procedure on the human teeth or jaw or associated structures<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /><ref name="Fraser_1995" /> * correcting malpositions of the human teeth or jaw or associated structures;<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /><ref name="Fraser_1995" /> * fitting or intra-orally adjusting artificial teeth or corrective or restorative dental appliances for a person<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /><ref name="Fraser_1995" /> * performing any irreversible procedure on, or the giving of any treatment or advice to, a person that is preparatory to or for the purpose of fitting, inserting, adjusting, fixing, constructing, repairing or renewing artificial dentures or a restorative dental appliance<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /><ref name="Fraser_1995" />
Dental Assisting is not a registered profession in Australia and as such training courses are not mandatory, although those with nationally recognised qualifications will enjoy the benefits of higher wages and better employment opportunities.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" />
There is no formal training required of entry level dental assistants in order to commence or undertake work in private practice in Australia.<ref name="Chrisopoulos_2011">{{cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/768469756|title=Oral health and dental care in Australia : key facts and figures 2011 | first1 = Sergio | last1 = Chrisopoulos | first2 = Katie | last2 = Beckwith | first3 = Jane | last3 = Harford | name-list-format = vanc | date = 2011 | publisher = Australian Institute of Health and Welfare|isbn=978-1-74249-266-7|location=Canberra|oclc=768469756}}</ref> Most dental assistants gain practical experience at a place of employment although there are vocational qualifications which are nationally recognised and highly recommended for increasing a person's job prospects, remuneration, and professional development.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" />
The National Vocational Qualification HLT35015 Certificate III in Dental Assisting is the entry level of vocational training for dental assisting while HLT45015 Certificate IV in Dental Assisting are suitable for those who seek to further their skills and duties and elect units from particular streams such as dental radiography, oral health promotion, practice administration, general anaesthesia and conscious sedation.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /><ref name="Chrisopoulos_2011" /> These formal qualifications can be offered only by registered training organisations such as TAFE and professional associations while Certificate III in Dental Assisting may also be offered as a traineeship in most States of Australia and as a School-based Traineeship for years 11 and 12 in some States.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" /><ref name="Chrisopoulos_2011" />
Currently dental assistants are not required to be registered under the Dental Board of Australia or with any State and Territory Boards since dental assisting is not a registered profession. Dental Assistants who have attained a Certificate IV in Dental Assisting – Dental Radiography and are required to operate dental radiography apparatus as part of their job role, must hold a current license with the relevant state or territory Radiation Authority.<ref name="DAPA_Working_Australia" />
Dental assistants are strongly encouraged to have current vaccinations for Hepatitis B, and Tetanus along with the normal childhood vaccination recommendations (Measles, mumps, varicella, polio) and influenza. Many state and territory public health care facilities and training providers will require students and workers to present evidence of Hepatitis B immunity and the results of a criminal history check prior to commencing clinical placement. Most private dental clinics will also require employees to have current vaccination records and may also require workers to undertake annual influenza vaccinations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dapa.asn.au/home/dental-assistants|title=Becoming a Dental Assistant | website = The Dental Assistants Professional Association |access-date=2015-09-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.adavb.net/ForthePublic/DentalProfessions/DentalAssistant/tabid/230/language/en-AU/Default.aspx#ADAVB-the-voice-of-dentistry-in-Victoria-0101011101000011 |title=ADAVB > For the Public > Dental Professions > Dental Assistant | author = ADAVB| website = Australian Dental Association Victorian Branch Inc. | access-date=2018-05-18}}</ref>
=== United States of America === [[File:Flag_of_the_United_States.svg|thumb|Flag of the United States.]] According to Occupational Employment Statistics, in the USA in 2017 there are a total of 337,160 Dental Assistants:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes319091.htm#st|title=Dental Assistants| publisher = U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> they all should have the following personal qualities:<ref name = "Bird_2015">{{cite book | first1 = Doni L. | last1 = Bird | first2 = Debbie S. | last2 = Robinson | name-list-format = vanc | title = Modern dental assisting|date=2015|isbn=978-1-4557-7451-7| edition = 11th | location = St. Louis, Missouri | oclc = 870890506 }}</ref><ref name="Johnson2001">{{cite journal | vauthors = Johnson PM | title = International profiles of dental hygiene 1987 to 1998: a 19-nation comparative study | journal = International Dental Journal | volume = 51 | issue = 4 | pages = 313–24 | date = August 2001 | pmid = 11570548 | doi = 10.1002/j.1875-595x.2001.tb00844.x }}</ref><ref name="Spadaro_2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Spadaro SE | title = One profession, many hats | journal = Dental Assistant | volume = 78 | issue = 1 | pages = 4, 48 | date = January 2009 | pmid = 19260391 }}</ref>
* demonstrate sensitivity to the patient's needs * show empathy<ref name="Spadaro_2009" /> * "say the right thing at the right time" * be sincere * be a good listener * be trust worthy
Unlike Australia, in the USA dental assisting is a registered profession represented by the American Dental Assistants Association (ADAA)<ref>{{cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/57251365|title=Materials and procedures for today's dental assistant | first = Ellen | last = Dietz-Bourguignon | name-list-format = vanc |date=2006|publisher=Thomson Delmar Learning|isbn=978-1-4018-3733-4|location=Clifton Park, NY|oclc=57251365}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Weber K | title = Is your dental assistant practicing legally? | journal = The Journal of the Michigan Dental Association | volume = 93 | issue = 11 | pages = 50–5 | date = November 2011 | pmid = 22235567 }}</ref> and members should possess both front desk and chairside skills.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/71798091|title=The administrative dental assistant | first1 = Linda J | last1 = Gaylor | name-list-format = vanc | date=2007|publisher=Saunders|isbn=978-1-4160-2566-5|edition=2nd |location=St. Louis, Mo.|oclc=71798091}}</ref>
Routine duties include:<ref>{{cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/778040161|title=Clinical primer : a pocket guide for dental assistants | first = Melanie | last = Mitchell | name-list-format = vanc |date=2013|publisher=Wolters Kluwer Health/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-1-4511-0508-7|edition=2nd |location=Philadelphia|oclc=778040161}}</ref><ref name="Johnson2001" /><ref name = "Bird_2015" />
* Ensure that patients are comfortable in the dental chair * Prepare patients and the work area for treatments and procedures * Sterilize dental instruments * Hand instruments to dentists during procedures * Dry patients’ mouths using suction hoses and other equipment * Instruct patients in proper oral hygiene * Process x rays and complete lab tasks, under the direction of a dentist * Keep records of dental treatments * Schedule patient appointments * Work with patients on billing and payment
Extended duties may include:<ref name = "BLS">{{cite web|url=https://www.bls.gov/ooh/healthcare/dental-assistants.htm#tab-2|title=Dental Assistants: Occupational Outlook Handbook | publisher = U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics | access-date = 2018-05-16 }}</ref><ref name="Stanislav_2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Stanislav L | title = Expanded duties and dental assistant education | journal = The Journal of the Tennessee Dental Association | volume = 90 | issue = 1 | pages = 14 | date = 2010 | pmid = 20361582 }}</ref>
* Coronal polishing * Sealant application * Fluoride application * Topical anesthetic application
==== Education and licensing ==== In some U.S. states, dental assistants can work in the field without a college degree, while in other states, dental assistants must be licensed or registered/<ref name = "Bird_2015" />
Dental assistants can receive formal education through academic programs at community colleges, vocational schools, career colleges, technical institutes, universities and dental schools with most programs needing only 8 to 11 months to complete.<ref name = "Bird_2015" />
The Commission on Dental Accreditation of the American Dental Association accredits dental assisting school programs, of which there are over 200 in the United States.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.ada.org/en/coda | title = Commission on Dental Accreditation (CODA) | website = Commission on Dental Accreditation | access-date = 2018-05-16 }}</ref>
To become a Certified Dental Assistant, or CDA, dental assistants must take the DANB (Dental Assisting National Board) CDA examination after they have completed an accredited dental assisting program,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.danb.org/Home/Become-Certified/Exams-and-Certifications.aspx|title=Exams & Certifications| website = Dental Assisting National Board, Inc |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref> while those who have been trained on the job or have graduated from non-accredited programs are eligible to take the national certification examination after they have completed two years of full-time work experience as dental assistants.<ref name="ADA_Education">{{cite web|url=https://www.ada.org/en/education-careers/careers-in-dentistry/dental-team-careers/dental-assistant/education-training-requirements-dental-assistant|title=Dental Assistant Education and Training Requirements| website = American Dental Association |access-date=2018-05-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Michigan Dental Association | title = The MDA's new policy on non-accredited dental assistant training programs | journal = The Journal of the Michigan Dental Association | volume = 89 | issue = 8 | pages = 50, 52–3 | date = August 2007 | pmid = 17844678 }}</ref> Some dentists are willing to pay a dental assistant-in-training that has a good attitude and work ethic.<ref name="ADA_Education" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hernandez A, Montellano V | title = Integrity, service and excellence: the experiences of USAF dental assistant instructors | journal = Dental Assistant | volume = 80 | issue = 6 | pages = 40–1 | date = November 2011 | pmid = 22359820 }}</ref>
In the USA the Dental Assisting National Board offers three nationally recognised certifications, namely:<ref name = "Bird_2015" />
# Certified Dental Assistant (CDA) # Certified Orthodontic Assistant (COA) # Certified Preventative Functions Dental Assistant (CPFDA)
Expanded duties dental assistants or expanded functions dental assistants,<ref>{{cite journal|date=1987-09-23|title=Directions: Above and beyond the call of duty |journal=Nursing Standard|volume=1|issue=3|pages=20|doi=10.7748/ns.1.3.20.s53 }}</ref> as they are known in some states, may work one on one with the patient performing restorations after the doctor has removed decay<ref name = "BLS" /><ref name="Stanislav_2010" /> Ideally, a dental assistant should have both administrative and clinical skills although it's still acceptable to have one or the other.
Duties may also include seating and preparing the patient, charting, mixing dental materials, providing patient education and post-operative instructions. They also keep track with inventory control and ordering supplies.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.vocationaltraininghq.com/how-to-become/dental-assistant/ | title = How to Become a Dental Assistant | website = Vocational Training }}</ref>
===United Kingdom === [[File:Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom_(3-5).svg|thumb|Flag of the United Kingdom (3-5).]] In the UK, [[Registered Dental Nurse]]s are prohibited from carrying out any form of direct dental treatment on the patient, including teeth whitening procedures, under the GDC scope of practice.<ref name = "Miller_2011">{{cite book | first1 = Mary | last1 = Miller | first2 = Crispian | last2 = Scully | name-list-format = vanc | title = Mosby's textbook of dental nursing | date = 2011 | publisher = Elsevier | location = Edinburgh | isbn = 978-0-7234-3506-8 | oclc=660502613 | pages = 71–2 }}</ref> Dental nurses found to be carrying out dental procedures are liable to be removed from the statutory GDC register.<ref name = "NHS_dental_nurse">{{cite web | url = https://www.healthcareers.nhs.uk/explore-roles/dental-team/roles-dental-team/dental-nurse|title=Dental nurse |date=2014-10-07 | website = Health Careers - National Health Service United Kingdom | access-date = 16 May 2018 }}</ref>
Duties include:<ref name = "NHS_dental_nurse" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Al Jazairy YH, Halawany HS, Hussainan NA, Maflehi NA, Abraham NB, Jacob V | title = Factors affecting job satisfaction and their correlation with educational standards among dental assistants | journal = Industrial Health | volume = 52 | issue = 4 | pages = 324–33 | date = 2014 | pmid = 24747371 | pmc = 4243018 | doi = 10.2486/indhealth.2014-0005 }}</ref>
* taking responsibility for the decontamination of instruments * maintaining dental operating equipment * ensuring that all relevant materials and supplies are in place * looking after patient records – including making notes when the dentist is examining a patient * working closely with the dentist, responding quickly to requests and generally keeping the surgery ready for use
Those with additional training or skills developed during their careers can undertake expanded duties that may include:<ref name = "Miller_2011" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Durkan C, Belsi A, Johnson R, Gallagher J | title = Career choice, pathways and continuing professional development of dental nurses at one institution | journal = British Dental Journal | volume = 213 | issue = 2 | pages = E1 | date = July 2012 | pmid = 22836443 | doi = 10.1038/sj.bdj.2012.663 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Pavitt SH, Baxter PD, Brunton PA, Douglas G, Edlin R, Gibson BJ, Godson J, Hall M, Porritt J, Robinson PG, Vinall K, Hulme C | title = The INCENTIVE protocol: an evaluation of the organisation and delivery of NHS dental healthcare to patients-innovation in the commissioning of primary dental care service delivery and organisation in the UK | journal = BMJ Open | volume = 4 | issue = 9 | pages = e005931 | date = September 2014 | pmid = 25231492 | pmc = 4166246 | doi = 10.1136/bmjopen-2014-005931 }}</ref>
* providing oral health education and health promotion * assisting in the treatment of patients under conscious sedation * assisting in the treatment of patients with special needs * intra-oral photography * shade taking * placing rubber dam * measuring and recording plaque indices * pouring, casting and trimming study models * removing sutures after the wound has been checked by a clinician * apply fluoride varnish as part of programme that is overseen by a consultant or specialist in a public dental health setting * constructing occlusal registration rims and special trays * repairing acrylic components of removable appliances * tracing cephalograms
Entry level working as a trainee dental nurse does not require any qualification, but progression to qualified dental nurse requires completion of a formal course of study, either part or full-time, approved by the General Dental Council. A minimum 2 GCSEs (C grade or above) in English language and maths or a science subject are usually required for part-time courses while full-time courses may require evidence of A-level or AS-level study. A level 3 apprenticeship in dental nursing is an alternative pathway to gaining the required qualifications in dental nursing.<ref name = "NHS_dental_nurse" />
===Ireland === [[File:Flag_of_Ireland.svg|thumb|Flag of Ireland.]] In Ireland dental assistants have the following tasks:<ref name = "IDA_Dental_nurse" /><ref name="Gorter_2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Gorter RC, Freeman R | title = Burnout and engagement in relation with job demands and resources among dental staff in Northern Ireland | journal = Community Dentistry and Oral Epidemiology | volume = 39 | issue = 1 | pages = 87–95 | date = February 2011 | pmid = 20735447 | doi = 10.1111/j.1600-0528.2010.00568.x }}</ref>
* infection control * chair-side assistance * preparation and maintenance of the dental surgery * patient care * and administration of the dental surgery
'''Skills Required'''<ref name = "IDA_Dental_nurse" /><ref name="Gorter_2011" />
* communication and organisation skills * the ability to use initiative * good manual dexterity * and be prepared to work closely providing support & assistance during the provision of dental treatment
In the Republic of Ireland, it is often dental nurses (and teeth whitening technicians) who carry out teeth whitening procedures rather than dentists.<ref name="Sheridan_2011">{{cite journal|last=Sheridan|first=Carmen | name-list-format = vanc |date= January 2011|title=Dental nursing abroad: rules, regulations and requirements 6|journal=Dental Nursing|volume=7|issue=1|pages=36–40|doi=10.12968/denn.2011.7.1.36 }}</ref>
This practice mainly occurs in clinics focusing solely on laser teeth whitening. In Ireland, registration as a dental nurse with The Irish Dental Council is voluntary; however, nurses who are registered and who carry out teeth whitening may face disciplinary action if caught.<ref name = "IDA_Dental_nurse">{{cite web | title = Dental Nurses | url = https://www.dentist.ie/careers-in-dentistry/dental-nurse.144.html | website = Irish Dental Association (IDA) | date = 16 May 2018 }}</ref><ref name="Sheridan_2011" />
